awd_titl_txt: RUI: Structural and enumerative problems on simplicial complexes
awd_abstract_narration:
Simplicial complexes are discrete objects that are used to approximate familiar geometric spaces. They are rooted in the historical development of many branches of mathematics, dating back to work of Euler in the 1700s.  Over the past fifty years, the field of geometric combinatorics has experienced tremendous growth.  The discrete nature of simplicial complexes makes them well-suited to computer implementations, and they continue to have practical modern applications in the fields of mathematical biology, optimization, statistical data analysis, and computer graphics. This project also encompasses mathematical outreach with middle and high school students, along with a commitment to involving undergraduate students in research projects.  This grant will support these endeavors by providing students with technical training and exposing them to the excitement of engaging in original scientific research.

The objective of the research is to further our understanding of the interplay between the topological and combinatorial structures of certain families of simplicial complexes.  Specifically, we seek to understand how certain conditions, such as graph colorability or matroidal structures, affect the combinatorial structure of certain families of simplicial complexes.  The problems are based in combinatorial geometry, but employ tools from, and have had applications to, the fields of commutative algebra, discrete geometry, algebraic topology, and algebraic geometry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The main scientific goal of this grant was to explore structural results in combinatorial geometry. The PI and his collaborators have contributed several results in this area, including results on rigidity of centrally symmetric polytopes, diameter bounds for graphs of oriented matroids, and explicit constructions of pure multicomplexes arising from PS-ear decomposable simplicial complexes in rank 3. 

Next, in a series of papers, the PI and his collaborators have reframed classical results related to Kirchhoff?s Matrix Tree Theorem through the lens of rank-one updates to the Laplacian matrix. This has led to elegant proofs of several classical results on spanning tree enumeration of simple and weighted graphs, including direct enumeration and spectral results for many famous families of graphs, along with sharp upper bounds for arbitrary graphs in terms of their degree sequences.

In addition, this grant supported nine undergraduate research students, giving them the opportunity to apply their mathematical knowledge to original research projects.  Involving undergraduate students in research projects has a strong impact on their development as STEM majors. Whether they choose to pursue an advanced degree in mathematics or not, the students gain valuable experience in exploring unsolved problems, formulating independent ideas, and learning to communicate those ideas with the broader scientific community.  

Finally, the PI is committed to training the next generation of STEM students through outreach programs for middle- and high school students. He organizes math circles, outreach lectures, and a unique oral olympiad for students from the greater Seattle area. This olympiad program shows students that there is more to mathematics than tricks and quickly solving problems on a timed test -- they are given three hours to solve seven problems; each problem can be attempted multiple times; and they must present their solutions orally to a team of judges who listen to the solution, ask questions, and provide feedback. To our knowledge, it is the only program of its kind in the United States. The PI coauthored a book on the olympiad, which includes problems and solutions from the first ten years of the program, along with a practical guide on how to organize an oral math olympiad.
